brief_description: Systems Biology Characterization in Early Life
brief_title: Small Sample- Big Data- Papua New Guinea Newborn Pilot Study
description: To enable characterization of the molecular ontogeny in early life, we developed a robust experimental and analytical approach that applies system biology tools to peripheral blood samples from human newborns
endpoints: transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, cytokine/chemokine, flow cytometry assays
hypothesis: There are rapid physiological changes that occur within days around birth.
objectives: To develop a robust SOP that would allow the extraction and analysis of data using systems biology approaches from small blood sample volumes.
official_title: Small Sample- Big Data: Systems Biology Reveals Dramatic Molecular Ontogeny over the First Week of Human Life

arm.description: This study with clinical site in Papua New Guinea aims to understand the impact of early life immunization. Characterizing vaccine-induced molecular patterns (signatures) that correspond to vaccine-mediated protection will accelerate development and optimization of vaccines against early life infections of major global health importance.
arm.name: EPIC002: Papua New Guinea pilot newborns

personnel.site_name: Boston Children's Hospital, Harvard Medical School

pubmed.title: Dynamic molecular changes during the first week of human life follow a robust developmental trajectory.
